canonical_explanation.text: Matter can be classified as pure substances and mixtures. Pure substances include elements (which cannot be broken down further) and compounds (which are formed by chemical combination of elements in a fixed ratio). Mixtures are formed by mixing two or more substances in any ratio without any chemical reaction. Mixtures can be homogeneous (uniform composition, like solutions) or heterogeneous (non-uniform composition, like sand and water). Solutions have a solute dissolved in a solvent. Suspensions have large particles that settle on standing. Colloids have intermediate-sized particles that show the Tyndall effect. Various separation techniques such as evaporation, distillation, chromatography, centrifugation, and crystallisation are used to separate mixtures based on the physical properties of their components.
rules: Pure substances have a fixed composition and definite properties.
Elements are the simplest form of matter and cannot be broken down further.
Compounds are formed by chemical combination of two or more elements in a fixed ratio.
Mixtures are formed by physical mixing and have no fixed composition.
Homogeneous mixtures (solutions) have uniform composition throughout.
A solution has a solute (dissolved substance) and a solvent (dissolving medium).
Suspensions have large particles that are visible, scatter light, and settle on standing.
Colloids have intermediate particles that show Tyndall effect but do not settle on standing.
Separation methods are based on differences in physical properties of components.
Physical changes are reversible and no new substance is formed.
Chemical changes are usually irreversible and new substances are formed.

questions.question_text: A pure substance that cannot be broken down into simpler substances by chemical means is called:
questions.explanation_correct: An element is a pure substance that cannot be broken down into simpler substances by any chemical or physical means. Elements are the basic building blocks of all matter. Examples include hydrogen, oxygen, iron, gold, and carbon.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A compound can be broken down into its constituent elements by chemical means. A mixture is not a pure substance. A solution is a type of homogeneous mixture. Only an element cannot be further decomposed by chemical reactions.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a compound?
questions.explanation_correct: Water (H2O) is a compound because it is formed by the chemical combination of two different elements — hydrogen and oxygen — in a fixed ratio of 2:1 by number of atoms. Compounds have different properties from their constituent elements.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Oxygen gas (O2), gold (Au), and iron (Fe) are all elements, not compounds. O2 is a molecule of an element (two atoms of the same element). Water (H2O) is a compound because it is made of two different elements chemically combined in a fixed ratio.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about compounds is correct?

options.text: Components can be separated by physical methods
Properties are the same as those of constituent elements
Components combine in a fixed ratio by mass

questions.explanation_correct: In a compound, elements combine in a fixed ratio by mass (law of constant proportions). For example, in water, hydrogen and oxygen always combine in a 1:8 ratio by mass. Components of a compound can only be separated by chemical methods, not physical ones.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Compounds cannot be separated by physical methods — only chemical methods work. Components combine in a fixed ratio, not any ratio (that describes mixtures). The properties of a compound are entirely different from those of its constituent elements (e.g., NaCl is very different from Na and Cl2).

questions.question_text: Sodium is a reactive metal and chlorine is a poisonous gas, yet sodium chloride (common salt) is safe to eat. This shows that:

options.text: Compounds retain the properties of their elements
Compounds have properties different from their constituent elements
Sodium and chlorine are not really dangerous
Salt is a mixture, not a compound

questions.explanation_correct: This demonstrates that compounds have properties entirely different from those of their constituent elements. Sodium (a reactive metal) and chlorine (a poisonous gas) chemically combine to form sodium chloride (common salt), which is a stable, non-toxic compound essential for life.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Compounds do NOT retain the properties of their elements. The fact that a reactive metal and a poisonous gas form an edible salt clearly demonstrates that chemical combination produces entirely new properties. Salt is indeed a compound, not a mixture.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly differentiates an element from a compound?

options.text: Elements are always solids; compounds can be any state
Elements contain only one type of atom; compounds contain two or more types of atoms chemically bonded
Elements are always found in nature; compounds are only man-made
Elements are always lighter than compounds

questions.explanation_correct: An element consists of only one type of atom (e.g., iron has only iron atoms), while a compound consists of two or more different types of atoms chemically bonded together in a fixed ratio (e.g., water has hydrogen and oxygen atoms bonded together).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Elements exist in all three states (iron is solid, mercury is liquid, oxygen is gas). Many compounds exist naturally (water, carbon dioxide). There is no rule that elements are lighter than compounds. The correct distinction is based on the types of atoms: one type for elements, multiple types chemically bonded for compounds.

questions.question_text: A mixture that has a uniform composition throughout is called:
questions.explanation_correct: A homogeneous mixture has a uniform composition throughout — its components are evenly distributed. Examples include solutions like salt water, sugar water, and air. You cannot distinguish the individual components visually.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A heterogeneous mixture does NOT have uniform composition. A compound is a pure substance, not a mixture. A suspension is a type of heterogeneous mixture. Only a homogeneous mixture has uniform composition where all parts are identical.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a heterogeneous mixture?
questions.explanation_correct: Sand mixed with water is a heterogeneous mixture because sand does not dissolve in water. The composition is non-uniform — you can clearly see the sand particles separately from the water. The sand eventually settles at the bottom.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Salt water, sugar water, and vinegar are all homogeneous mixtures (solutions) where the solute is completely dissolved and the composition is uniform throughout. Sand in water is heterogeneous because sand particles do not dissolve and can be seen separately.

questions.question_text: Air is classified as a:
questions.explanation_correct: Air is a homogeneous mixture of gases (nitrogen, oxygen, carbon dioxide, argon, water vapour, and others). The composition is uniform throughout a given sample, and the components are not chemically bonded. Its composition can vary from place to place, confirming it is a mixture, not a compound.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Air is not a compound because its composition is not fixed and its components are not chemically bonded. It is not an element because it contains multiple types of atoms/molecules. It is not heterogeneous because the gases are uniformly mixed. Air is a homogeneous mixture.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a key difference between a mixture and a compound?

options.text: Mixtures always have two components while compounds can have many
Components of a mixture can be separated by physical methods, but compounds require chemical methods
Compounds are always in liquid form

questions.explanation_correct: A key difference is that components of a mixture can be separated by physical methods (filtration, evaporation, distillation, etc.) because they are only physically mixed. In a compound, elements are chemically bonded, so chemical methods are needed to separate them.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both mixtures and compounds can have two or more components. Compounds can be solid, liquid, or gas. Mixtures may or may not have uniform composition (homogeneous vs heterogeneous). The correct distinguishing factor is the method of separation: physical for mixtures, chemical for compounds.

questions.question_text: In a solution, the substance that is dissolved is called the:
questions.explanation_correct: In a solution, the solute is the substance that is dissolved. The solvent is the substance that does the dissolving. For example, in a salt solution, salt is the solute and water is the solvent. Generally, the component present in smaller quantity is the solute.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The solvent is the substance in which the solute is dissolved, not the dissolved substance itself. Residue is what remains after filtration. Filtrate is the liquid that passes through a filter. The dissolved substance in a solution is called the solute.

questions.question_text: A solution in which no more solute can be dissolved at a given temperature is called:
questions.explanation_correct: A saturated solution is one in which no more solute can be dissolved at a given temperature. The solution has reached its maximum capacity to dissolve the solute. If more solute is added, it will remain undissolved at the bottom.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An unsaturated solution can still dissolve more solute. A supersaturated solution contains more dissolved solute than a saturated solution (usually prepared by cooling a hot saturated solution). A dilute solution has relatively less solute. The term for the maximum dissolved state is a saturated solution.

questions.question_text: Which property is characteristic of a suspension?

options.text: Particles are not visible to the naked eye
It shows the Tyndall effect but particles do not settle

questions.explanation_correct: In a suspension, the solute particles are large enough to be seen with the naked eye and they settle down when the suspension is left undisturbed. Examples include muddy water, chalk in water, and sand in water. Suspensions are heterogeneous mixtures.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In suspensions, particles ARE visible to the naked eye (unlike solutions). Suspensions are heterogeneous, not homogeneous. Colloids show the Tyndall effect without settling. The defining characteristic of a suspension is that its large particles settle down on standing due to gravity.

questions.question_text: Milk is classified as a:
questions.explanation_correct: Milk is a colloid (specifically an emulsion). The fat droplets in milk are intermediate in size between solution particles and suspension particles. They do not settle on standing and show the Tyndall effect when a beam of light is passed through milk.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Milk is not a true solution because the fat particles are larger than solute particles in a solution. It is not a suspension because the particles do not settle on standing. It is not a compound because its components are not chemically bonded. Milk is a colloid — an emulsion of fat in water.

questions.question_text: The Tyndall effect is observed when:

options.text: A beam of light passes through a true solution
A beam of light passes through a colloidal solution
Light is reflected from a mirror

questions.explanation_correct: The Tyndall effect is the scattering of a beam of light when it passes through a colloidal solution. The colloidal particles are large enough to scatter light, making the path of the light beam visible. This does not happen in a true solution where particles are too small to scatter light.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Tyndall effect does not occur in true solutions because the solute particles are too small to scatter light. It specifically occurs in colloids where the particles are of intermediate size (1 nm to 1000 nm). It has nothing to do with mirrors or sound.

questions.question_text: The concentration of a solution is expressed as mass by mass percentage. If 20 g of salt is dissolved in 180 g of water, the concentration is:
questions.explanation_correct: Mass by mass percentage = (Mass of solute / Mass of solution) × 100 = (20 / (20 + 180)) × 100 = (20 / 200) × 100 = 10%. The mass of the solution is the total of solute mass plus solvent mass.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct calculation is: concentration = (mass of solute / mass of solution) × 100. Mass of solution = mass of solute + mass of solvent = 20 + 180 = 200 g. So concentration = (20/200) × 100 = 10%. Remember, we divide by the total mass of solution, not by the mass of solvent alone.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly arranges solution, colloid, and suspension in order of increasing particle size?
questions.explanation_correct: In order of increasing particle size: Solution (< 1 nm) < Colloid (1 nm to 1000 nm) < Suspension (> 1000 nm). Solution particles are the smallest and cannot be seen. Colloid particles are intermediate. Suspension particles are the largest and are visible.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct order is Solution < Colloid < Suspension. Solutions have the smallest particles (< 1 nm), colloids have intermediate particles (1-1000 nm), and suspensions have the largest particles (> 1000 nm). This difference in particle size determines their properties like visibility, settling behaviour, and light scattering.

questions.question_text: Which method is used to separate a mixture of salt and water?
questions.explanation_correct: Evaporation is used to separate salt from water. When the salt solution is heated, the water evaporates, leaving behind the solid salt. This method works because salt has a much higher boiling point than water and does not evaporate with it.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Filtration cannot separate dissolved salt from water because salt particles in solution are too small to be trapped by a filter. Sieving is used for particles of different sizes. Magnetic separation is for magnetic and non-magnetic substances. Evaporation is the correct method for separating a dissolved solid from its solvent.

questions.question_text: Which separation technique is used to separate a mixture of two miscible liquids with different boiling points?
questions.explanation_correct: Distillation is used to separate miscible liquids that have different boiling points. The mixture is heated; the liquid with the lower boiling point vaporises first, and the vapour is then condensed and collected separately. Simple distillation works when the boiling point difference is significant.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Filtration is for separating insoluble solids from liquids. Evaporation would remove all liquid, not separate two liquids. Chromatography separates components based on differential migration. Distillation uses the difference in boiling points to separate miscible liquids.

questions.question_text: To separate a mixture of two miscible liquids whose boiling points are very close (within 25°C), we should use:
questions.explanation_correct: Fractional distillation is used when the boiling points of two miscible liquids are very close (less than 25°C apart). A fractionating column provides multiple stages of condensation and evaporation, allowing better separation. Simple distillation is not effective for close boiling points.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Simple distillation is effective only when the boiling points differ by 25°C or more. For closer boiling points, fractional distillation is needed because the fractionating column provides additional surfaces for repeated condensation and vaporisation, achieving better separation.

questions.question_text: Chromatography is based on the principle that different components of a mixture:

options.text: Are adsorbed to different extents on an adsorbent

questions.explanation_correct: Chromatography works on the principle that different components of a mixture are adsorbed to different extents on an adsorbent (stationary phase). Components that are more strongly adsorbed move slowly, while those that are less strongly adsorbed move faster with the solvent (mobile phase).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Chromatography is not based on density differences, melting points, or chemical reactions with acids. It relies on the differential adsorption of components on a stationary phase. Components separate because they travel at different rates through the medium due to varying affinities for the adsorbent.

questions.question_text: Centrifugation is used to separate:

options.text: A dissolved solid from a liquid
Fine suspended particles from a liquid

questions.explanation_correct: Centrifugation is used to separate fine suspended particles from a liquid by spinning the mixture at high speed. The denser particles are forced to the bottom, and the lighter liquid stays at the top. It is used in dairies to separate cream from milk and in diagnostic labs to separate blood components.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Centrifugation is specifically for separating fine insoluble particles from liquids when normal filtration is too slow. It does not separate miscible liquids (use distillation), dissolved solids (use evaporation), or gases from liquids. It uses centrifugal force to speed up the settling of fine particles.

questions.question_text: Which method would you use to obtain pure crystals of copper sulphate from an impure sample?
questions.explanation_correct: Crystallisation is used to obtain pure crystals from an impure solid sample. The impure substance is dissolved in a suitable solvent at high temperature to form a saturated solution, then cooled slowly. Pure crystals form as the solution cools, while impurities remain in the solution.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Filtration separates insoluble solids from liquids. Distillation separates liquids based on boiling points. Centrifugation separates fine particles. Crystallisation is the correct method for obtaining pure crystals, as it produces well-formed crystals with high purity by leaving impurities dissolved in the mother liquor.

questions.question_text: To separate ammonium chloride from a mixture of ammonium chloride and common salt, the most appropriate method is:
questions.explanation_correct: Sublimation is the appropriate method because ammonium chloride sublimes (changes directly from solid to gas) on heating, while common salt does not. When the mixture is heated, ammonium chloride vapour rises and can be collected by cooling, leaving the salt behind.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Filtration cannot separate two solids. Distillation is for liquid mixtures. Chromatography is for separating components based on adsorption. Since ammonium chloride sublimes but salt does not, sublimation is the ideal method — the ammonium chloride vapour can be collected separately.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a physical change?
questions.explanation_correct: Melting of ice is a physical change because it only changes the state of water from solid to liquid. No new substance is formed, the chemical composition (H2O) remains the same, and the change is reversible — liquid water can be frozen back into ice.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Burning of paper, rusting of iron, and cooking of food are all chemical changes because new substances are formed and the changes are generally irreversible. Only melting of ice is a physical change — it merely changes the state without altering the chemical identity of the substance.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a chemical change?
questions.explanation_correct: Digestion of food is a chemical change because the complex food molecules are broken down into simpler substances by enzymes and acids. New substances are formed, and the process is irreversible. The chemical composition of the food changes completely during digestion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Dissolving sugar in water, cutting cloth, and breaking glass are all physical changes because no new substances are formed and the chemical composition remains unchanged. Digestion is a chemical change because food is chemically broken down into entirely new substances.

questions.question_text: Which of the following processes involves both a physical and a chemical change?
questions.explanation_correct: Burning of a candle involves both physical and chemical changes. The melting of wax is a physical change (solid to liquid), while the burning of the wax vapour is a chemical change (wax reacts with oxygen to form carbon dioxide and water).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Melting of wax, evaporation of water, and dissolving salt are all purely physical changes. Only the burning of a candle involves both: the physical change of wax melting and the chemical change of the wax vapour combusting (reacting with oxygen) to produce new substances.

questions.question_text: Elements can be classified into metals, non-metals, and metalloids. Which of the following is a metalloid?
questions.explanation_correct: Silicon is a metalloid — it has properties intermediate between metals and non-metals. Other metalloids include boron, germanium, and arsenic. Iron is a metal, and sulphur and nitrogen are non-metals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Iron is a metal, not a metalloid. Sulphur and nitrogen are non-metals. Silicon is a metalloid because it shows properties of both metals and non-metals — for example, it looks shiny like a metal but is a poor conductor of electricity compared to metals.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a property of a colloidal solution?

options.text: It appears homogeneous but is actually heterogeneous
Its particles can be separated by ordinary filtration
Its particles do not settle on their own

questions.explanation_correct: Colloidal particles cannot be separated by ordinary filtration because they are small enough to pass through filter paper. Colloids require special techniques like centrifugation for separation. Colloids do show the Tyndall effect, are heterogeneous in nature (despite appearing homogeneous), and their particles do not settle on standing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Colloidal particles are too small to be trapped by ordinary filter paper, so they pass right through. Colloids do show Tyndall effect, are actually heterogeneous (despite appearing homogeneous), and their particles are stable enough not to settle on standing. The inability to filter them is what distinguishes colloids from suspensions.

questions.question_text: An alloy such as brass (copper + zinc) is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: Brass is a homogeneous mixture of copper and zinc. It is a mixture because the metals are physically combined and can be present in varying ratios. It is homogeneous because the composition is uniform throughout. Alloys are typically classified as homogeneous solid mixtures.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Brass is not a compound because its components are not in a fixed ratio and are not chemically bonded. It is not an element because it contains more than one type of atom. It is not heterogeneous because the composition is uniform. Alloys like brass are homogeneous mixtures of metals.

questions.question_text: To separate a mixture of oil and water, the most appropriate method is:
questions.explanation_correct: A separating funnel is used to separate immiscible liquids like oil and water. Oil and water do not mix and form two separate layers due to their different densities. In a separating funnel, the stopcock is opened to drain out the lower (denser) layer, leaving the upper layer behind.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Evaporation would remove both liquids. Distillation is for miscible liquids with different boiling points. Chromatography is for separating mixtures based on adsorption. Since oil and water are immiscible and form distinct layers, a separating funnel is the simplest and most effective method.

questions.question_text: Elements are pure substances that contain only one type of atom.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Elements are pure substances made up of only one type of atom. For example, gold contains only gold atoms, and oxygen contains only oxygen atoms. Elements cannot be broken down into simpler substances by chemical means.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. By definition, an element consists of only one type of atom. Each element has a unique atomic number and cannot be decomposed into simpler substances by chemical reactions.

questions.question_text: A mixture always has a fixed composition like a compound.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. Unlike compounds, mixtures do NOT have a fixed composition. The components of a mixture can be mixed in any proportion. For example, a salt solution can have different amounts of salt dissolved in the same amount of water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. Compounds have a fixed ratio of components, but mixtures can have their components in any ratio. This is a key difference between compounds (fixed composition) and mixtures (variable composition).

questions.question_text: A true solution scatters light and shows the Tyndall effect.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. A true solution does NOT show the Tyndall effect because its solute particles are too small (less than 1 nm) to scatter light. Only colloidal solutions show the Tyndall effect because their particles (1-1000 nm) are large enough to scatter a beam of light.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. True solutions have particles smaller than 1 nm which cannot scatter light. The Tyndall effect is observed only in colloids where particles are large enough (1-1000 nm) to scatter a beam of light, making the path of light visible.

questions.question_text: Rusting of iron is a physical change because the iron can be recovered.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. Rusting of iron is a chemical change, not a physical change. A new substance — iron oxide (rust) — is formed when iron reacts with oxygen and moisture. The iron cannot simply be recovered from rust by physical means; a chemical reaction would be needed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. Rusting is a chemical change because iron reacts with oxygen and moisture to form a new substance (iron oxide or rust). Chemical changes produce new substances with different properties and are generally irreversible by simple physical methods.

questions.question_text: Crystallisation is a better technique than evaporation for obtaining pure solid substances because evaporation can decompose heat-sensitive substances.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Crystallisation is often preferred over simple evaporation because (1) evaporation may decompose substances that are sensitive to high temperatures, (2) evaporation may leave impurities in the solid, and (3) crystallisation produces purer, well-formed crystals with fewer impurities.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Crystallisation is advantageous over evaporation for purification because it avoids exposing heat-sensitive compounds to high temperatures and produces purer products by leaving impurities in the mother liquor.

questions.question_text: Hydrogen and oxygen gases mixed together in a container form a compound.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. Simply mixing hydrogen and oxygen gases in a container creates a mixture, not a compound. To form a compound (water), a chemical reaction must occur — the gases need to combine chemically (e.g., through ignition or a catalyst). Mere physical mixing does not create a compound.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. A compound is formed only through a chemical reaction, not by mere physical mixing. Mixing hydrogen and oxygen gases in a container produces a mixture of the two gases. A chemical reaction (such as combustion) is required to form the compound water (H2O).

questions.question_text: Elements that have properties of both metals and non-metals are called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Elements that show properties intermediate between metals and non-metals are called metalloids (or semi-metals). Examples include boron, silicon, germanium, and arsenic. They may look shiny like metals but conduct electricity less efficiently.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'metalloids'. These elements (like silicon and boron) exhibit properties that are intermediate between metals and non-metals, such as intermediate conductivity, making them useful in semiconductors.

questions.question_text: A mixture that has a non-uniform composition and whose components can be distinguished visually is called a ___ mixture.
questions.explanation_correct: A heterogeneous mixture has a non-uniform composition — different parts of the mixture have different compositions. The components can often be seen and distinguished visually. Examples include sand and water, oil and water, and a salad.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'heterogeneous'. Heterogeneous mixtures have visibly different components with non-uniform composition. In contrast, homogeneous mixtures have uniform composition throughout and components cannot be visually distinguished.

questions.question_text: The scattering of a beam of light by colloidal particles is called the ___ effect.
questions.explanation_correct: The Tyndall effect is the phenomenon of scattering of light by colloidal particles. When a beam of light passes through a colloid, the path becomes visible because the colloidal particles are large enough to scatter the light. This effect is named after the scientist John Tyndall.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'Tyndall'. The Tyndall effect occurs in colloids because their particles (1-1000 nm) are large enough to scatter light. This effect helps distinguish colloids from true solutions, which do not scatter light.

questions.question_text: The technique used to separate the coloured components (dyes) of ink is ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Chromatography is used to separate the coloured components of ink. The different dyes in ink are adsorbed to different extents on paper (or another adsorbent) and travel different distances with the solvent, resulting in separation. The name comes from 'chroma' meaning colour.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'chromatography'. This technique separates the different coloured dyes in ink based on their different rates of movement through an adsorbent. Each dye has a different affinity for the paper and the solvent, causing them to separate into distinct bands.

questions.question_text: A solution in which more solute can still be dissolved at a given temperature is called an ___ solution.
questions.explanation_correct: An unsaturated solution is one in which more solute can still be dissolved at a given temperature. It contains less solute than the maximum amount that can be dissolved. Adding more solute to an unsaturated solution will result in the solute dissolving.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'unsaturated'. An unsaturated solution has not reached its maximum dissolving capacity at a given temperature. In contrast, a saturated solution cannot dissolve any more solute, and a supersaturated solution contains more solute than the saturation limit.

questions.question_text: A change in which new substances are formed with different properties is called a ___ change.
questions.explanation_correct: A chemical change (or chemical reaction) is a change in which one or more new substances are formed with different properties from the original substances. Chemical changes are usually irreversible. Examples include burning, rusting, cooking, and digestion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'chemical'. In a chemical change, the chemical composition and properties of the substance change, producing entirely new substances. This is different from a physical change where only the physical state or appearance changes without forming new substances.

questions.question_text: Smoke is an example of which type of colloid?
questions.explanation_correct: Smoke is an aerosol — a colloid in which tiny solid particles (carbon/soot) are dispersed in a gas (air). The solid particles are small enough to remain suspended in the air without settling, which is characteristic of a colloidal system.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Smoke consists of tiny solid particles suspended in air (gas), making it a solid-in-gas aerosol. A sol has solid in liquid (e.g., paint). A liquid aerosol has liquid in gas (e.g., fog). A foam has gas in liquid (e.g., shaving cream).

questions.question_text: Which of the following pairs represents a homogeneous and a heterogeneous mixture respectively?

options.text: Salt solution and oil in water
Sand in water and sugar solution

questions.explanation_correct: Salt solution is a homogeneous mixture (salt completely dissolves in water, giving uniform composition), and oil in water is a heterogeneous mixture (oil and water do not mix, forming two visible layers). This pair correctly represents one of each type.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mud water is heterogeneous and air is homogeneous (reverse of what is asked). Sand in water is heterogeneous and sugar solution is homogeneous (reverse order). The correct pair with homogeneous FIRST and heterogeneous SECOND is salt solution (homogeneous) and oil in water (heterogeneous).

questions.question_text: Which method is most suitable for separating a mixture of iron filings and sulphur powder?

options.text: Dissolving in carbon disulphide and filtering

questions.explanation_correct: Both methods work for separating iron filings from sulphur. Method A: sulphur dissolves in carbon disulphide while iron does not, so filtering separates them. Method B: iron is magnetic and can be picked up by a magnet, leaving sulphur behind. Both exploit different physical properties for separation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both methods are valid for this separation. A magnet attracts iron filings (magnetic property), and carbon disulphide dissolves sulphur but not iron (solubility property). These methods would not work if iron and sulphur had been chemically combined to form iron sulphide (a compound).

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about compounds is FALSE?

options.text: Properties of a compound are different from its constituent elements
A compound has a fixed melting and boiling point
Components of a compound can be separated by physical methods
A compound is a homogeneous substance

questions.explanation_correct: The statement 'Components of a compound can be separated by physical methods' is FALSE. Compounds can only be broken down into their constituent elements by chemical methods, not physical ones. This is because elements in a compound are chemically bonded together.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Statements A, B, and D are all true about compounds. Compounds DO have different properties from elements, they DO have fixed melting/boiling points, and they ARE homogeneous. The FALSE statement is C — compounds require chemical methods, not physical methods, for separation.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of a true solution?
questions.explanation_correct: Filtered lemonade is a true solution — the sugar, citric acid, and other components are completely dissolved in water, creating a homogeneous mixture with particles smaller than 1 nm. Milk and blood are colloids, and muddy water is a suspension.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Milk is a colloid (emulsion), muddy water is a suspension, and blood is a colloid. Filtered lemonade is a true solution because all its solutes are completely dissolved, the mixture is transparent (or translucent due to colour, not particles), and it does not show the Tyndall effect.

questions.question_text: Which one of the following is a chemical change?
questions.explanation_correct: Photosynthesis is a chemical change because new substances (glucose and oxygen) are formed from carbon dioxide and water using sunlight energy. The chemical composition of the reactants changes completely. This reaction is not easily reversible.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Tearing paper is a physical change (shape changes, but paper remains paper). Freezing water is a physical change (state change only). Dissolving sugar is a physical change (no new substance formed). Only photosynthesis is a chemical change — CO2 and H2O are chemically converted to glucose and O2.

questions.question_text: To obtain pure water from sea water, the most suitable technique is:
questions.explanation_correct: Distillation is the most suitable method to obtain pure water from sea water. Sea water is heated, and the water vapour rises and is condensed in a condenser to give pure water (distillate). The dissolved salts and impurities remain behind in the flask.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Filtration cannot remove dissolved salts. Evaporation would give you the salt, not the water. Sieving cannot separate dissolved substances. Distillation is correct because it evaporates the water (separating it from dissolved salts) and then condenses the vapour to collect pure water.

questions.question_text: Fog is a colloidal system in which:
questions.explanation_correct: Fog is a colloid in which tiny liquid water droplets are dispersed in gas (air). It is a type of aerosol (liquid in gas). The tiny water droplets are small enough to remain suspended in air and scatter light, which is why fog reduces visibility.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fog consists of tiny liquid water droplets suspended in air (gas), making it a liquid-in-gas colloid (aerosol). Solid in gas would be smoke. Gas in liquid would be foam. Liquid in liquid would be an emulsion like milk. Fog is specifically a liquid aerosol.
